title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula in the 7th century CE?

options.label: A
options.text: Abū Bakr

options.label: B
options.text: Muhammad

options.label: C
options.text: Ali

options.label: D
options.text: The Umayyad Dynasty

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the city that Muhammad established as the political heart of the Islamic Empire?

options.label: A
options.text: Mecca

options.label: B
options.text: Medina

options.label: C
options.text: Damascus

options.label: D
options.text: Baghdad

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary factor that contributed to the stabilization of the Umayyad Empire?

options.label: A
options.text: The replacement of local leaders with Muslim officials

options.label: B
options.text: The adoption of Arabic as the administrative language

options.label: C
options.text: The tolerance of local customs and religious preferences

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: Which dynasty overthrew the Umayyad caliphate in 750 CE?

options.label: A
options.text: The Abbasid Dynasty

options.label: B
options.text: The Umayyad Dynasty

options.label: C
options.text: The Mongol Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The Byzantine Empire

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the extensive trade networks established during the Abbasid rule?

options.label: A
options.text: The decline of the Islamic Empire

options.label: B
options.text: The rise of the Mongol Empire

options.label: C
options.text: The intermingling of cultures and knowledge leading to artistic and scientific advancements

options.label: D
options.text: The decline of the caliph's power

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary issue with the line of succession in the Abbasid Dynasty?

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of clear rules for succession

options.label: B
options.text: The limited number of eligible candidates

options.label: C
options.text: The dominance of the army officers in the selection process

options.label: D
options.text: The influence of external powers

multiple-choice.question: What event in 1258 CE marked the end of the united Islamic Empire?

options.label: A
options.text: The death of Muhammad

options.label: B
options.text: The overthrow of the Umayyad Dynasty

options.label: C
options.text: The siege of Baghdad by the Mongols

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of the Abbasid Dynasty

multiple-choice.question: What was the lasting impact of the Islamic Empire on the world?

options.label: A
options.text: The spread of Christianity

options.label: B
options.text: The establishment of the Mongol Empire

options.label: C
options.text: The influence of written and spoken Arabic, Islam, and the ideas of its greatest intellectuals

options.label: D
options.text: The decline of trade and cultural exchange

multiple-choice.question: How did the Umayyad Dynasty manage the diverse populations within their empire?

options.label: A
options.text: By imposing their own customs and language on the local populations

options.label: B
options.text: By replacing the local leaders with Muslim officials and allowing local customs to continue

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a new administrative language

options.label: D
options.text: By isolating the different populations from each other

multiple-choice.question: What was the consequence of the caliphs' symbolic rule in the later years of the Islamic Empire?

options.label: A
options.text: The increase in the caliph's power and influence

options.label: B
options.text: The growth of local leaders' power and refusal to pay taxes

options.label: C
options.text: The decline of trade and cultural exchange

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of the Mongol Empire

title: Can you guess what's wrong with these paintings? - Noah Charney

multiple-choice.question: Who is the 16th-century Italian painter to whom the defaced portrait was initially attributed?

options.label: A
options.text: Leonardo da Vinci

options.label: B
options.text: Bronzino

options.label: C
options.text: Michelangelo

options.label: D
options.text: Raphael

multiple-choice.question: What technology did the art conservator use to discover the countenance of a completely different woman under the outer surface of the defaced portrait?

options.label: A
options.text: Infrared technology

options.label: B
options.text: X-ray technology

options.label: C
options.text: Ultraviolet technology

options.label: D
options.text: Laser technology

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the approach of past art restorers and the approach used today?

options.label: A
options.text: Past restorers focused on minimal intervention, while modern restorers take a more heavy-handed approach.

options.label: B
options.text: Past restorers took a more heavy-handed approach, while modern restorers focus on minimal intervention.

options.label: C
options.text: Past restorers used varnish to protect paintings, while modern restorers do not.

options.label: D
options.text: Past restorers did not use varnish, while modern restorers do.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the conservator remove the outer varnish coat from the defaced portrait?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect the painting from debris

options.label: B
options.text: To make the colors pop

options.label: C
options.text: To recover the original painting

options.label: D
options.text: To add a new layer of varnish

multiple-choice.question: What was the likely reason for the Victorian makeover of the defaced portrait?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the subject more attractive

options.label: B
options.text: To make the subject less attractive

options.label: C
options.text: To boost sales

options.label: D
options.text: To change the subject's identity

multiple-choice.question: What was altered in Bronzino's "An Allegory with Venus and Cupid" to make it less risqué for Victorian England?

options.label: A
options.text: Venus's tongue and nipple were added

options.label: B
options.text: Venus's tongue and nipple were obscured

options.label: C
options.text: The veil covering Venus's crotch was removed

options.label: D
options.text: The branch hiding Cupid's posterior was removed

multiple-choice.question: What was used to neutralize the acid attack on Rembrandt's "The Night Watch"?

options.label: A
options.text: Water

options.label: B
options.text: Adhesive

options.label: C
options.text: Extra canvas backing

options.label: D
options.text: Varnish

multiple-choice.question: How did the conservators replace the missing pieces of "The Night Watch"?

options.label: A
options.text: By using an artificial intelligence to digitally paint in Rembrandt's style

options.label: B
options.text: By using another artist's rendering of the original

options.label: C
options.text: By printing the painting's lost sections

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of art conservators when restoring damaged or altered paintings?

options.label: A
options.text: To improve the painting's appearance

options.label: B
options.text: To change the painting's meaning

options.label: C
options.text: To immortalize priceless artifacts

options.label: D
options.text: To make the painting more valuable

options.label: A
options.text: Marriott Hotels

options.label: B
options.text: TED-Ed

options.label: C
options.text: National Gallery

options.label: D
options.text: Amsterdam's Town Hall

title: A brief history of Spanish - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary influence on the development of modern Spanish, accounting for approximately 75% of its composition?

options.label: A
options.text: Arabic

options.label: B
options.text: Indigenous languages of the Americas

options.label: C
options.text: Latin

options.label: D
options.text: Germanic languages

multiple-choice.question: Describe the impact of the Umayyad Caliphate on the Spanish language.

options.label: A
options.text: They introduced a significant number of Germanic loanwords.

options.label: B
options.text: They imposed their eastern Germanic language as the official language.

options.label: C
options.text: They left a strong mark, contributing over a thousand words, often starting with "a" or "z" sounds.

options.label: D
options.text: They eliminated the use of Latin in the region.

multiple-choice.question: If you were a language teacher, how would you explain the concept of noun gender in Spanish to a student who speaks a language without this feature?

options.label: A
options.text: Nouns have no gender in Spanish.

options.label: B
options.text: Nouns are either masculine or feminine, but it doesn't affect sentence structure.

options.label: C
options.text: Nouns are classified as masculine or feminine, influencing the choice of articles and adjectives.

options.label: D
options.text: Nouns can be both masculine and feminine, depending on the context.

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the factors that contributed to the adoption of Castilian as the official state language in 1492.

options.label: A
options.text: Its similarity to Latin and widespread use among the population.

options.label: B
options.text: The Catholic Church's preference for a unified language and the central location of the Kingdom of Castile.

options.label: C
options.text: The influence of Arabic and the Umayyad Caliphate.

options.label: D
options.text: The language's simplicity and ease of use.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Spanish conquest of the Americas in terms of language use among the Indigenous population?

options.label: A
options.text: Most Indigenous languages were preserved and continued to thrive.

options.label: B
options.text: A new language emerged, blending Spanish and Indigenous languages.

options.label: C
options.text: The use of Indigenous languages declined as Spanish became the dominant language.

options.label: D
options.text: The Indigenous population had no impact on the Spanish language.

multiple-choice.question: How did the French language influence Spanish during the 18th century?

options.label: A
options.text: French replaced Spanish as the official language in Spain.

options.label: B
options.text: Spanish gained new words from French due to cultural exchange and fashion.

options.label: C
options.text: French had no impact on the Spanish language.

options.label: D
options.text: Spanish influenced the development of French.

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the reasons why Spanish has not broken apart into new languages despite its widespread use and geographical distribution.

options.label: A
options.text: The language's unity is due to the consistent use of Latin roots and the Catholic Church's influence.

options.label: B
options.text: Spanish has retained enough unity in syntax, grammar, and vocabulary to remain one language.

options.label: C
options.text: The language's simplicity and ease of use have prevented it from diverging.

options.label: D
options.text: Colonialism and the imposition of Spanish as an official language have led to its fragmentation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of speakers of Spanish worldwide, and how does it compare to other languages?

options.label: A
options.text: Approximately 100 million, ranking it among the top 10 languages.

options.label: B
options.text: Around 415 million, making it the fourth most spoken language.

options.label: C
options.text: Over 1 billion, placing it as the most spoken language.

options.label: D
options.text: Less than 50 million, ranking it among the least spoken languages.

multiple-choice.question: Consider the example of Spanglish, a mixture of Spanish and English. What implications does this have for the classification of languages?

options.label: A
options.text: Spanglish is a distinct language that has emerged due to cultural exchange.

options.label: B
options.text: Spanglish is not a language, but rather a dialect or regional variation.

options.label: C
options.text: The existence of Spanglish suggests that language classification is subjective and context-dependent.

options.label: D
options.text: Spanglish has no implications for language classification.

multiple-choice.question: Synthesize the information about the historical development of Spanish and its current status as a global language. What can be inferred about the relationship between language, culture, and power?

options.label: A
options.text: Language is independent of culture and power dynamics.

options.label: B
options.text: The spread of a language is solely due to its linguistic features and simplicity.

options.label: C
options.text: Language is closely tied to culture and power, with dominant languages often influencing the development of others.

options.label: D
options.text: The history of Spanish is unique and does not reflect broader patterns in language development.

title: Why a sausage can do what your gloves cannot - Charles Wallace and Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: What unusual item did people in South Korea use to activate their smartphones during a particularly cold winter in 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: A stylus

options.label: B
options.text: A snack sausage

options.label: C
options.text: A pair of gloves

options.label: D
options.text: A banana peel

multiple-choice.question: What technology is used in both the first ever touchscreen and the first iPhone?

options.label: A
options.text: Resistive technology

options.label: B
options.text: Capacitive technology

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive technology

options.label: D
options.text: Insulating technology

multiple-choice.question: How do conductive materials differ from insulators?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductive materials have tightly bound electrons, while insulators have weakly bound electrons.

options.label: B
options.text: Conductive materials have weakly bound electrons, while insulators have tightly bound electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive materials have no electrons, while insulators have many electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive materials have many electrons, while insulators have no electrons.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the layers of a resistive touchscreen connect?

options.label: A
options.text: The electric circuit is broken.

options.label: B
options.text: The electric circuit is completed, causing a change in voltage.

options.label: C
options.text: The touchscreen becomes unresponsive.

options.label: D
options.text: The touchscreen is damaged.

multiple-choice.question: Why are capacitive touchscreens generally easier to use than resistive touchscreens?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they require the application of force.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they interact directly with your finger without the application of force.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are cheaper and more durable.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more responsive.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the human body a good conductor of electricity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is made up of mostly fat.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is made up of mostly bone.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is made up of mostly water, which is impure and contains ions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is made up of mostly muscle.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you touch a capacitive touchscreen with your finger?

options.label: A
options.text: Your finger interrupts the electrical connection between the phone and the screen.

options.label: B
options.text: Your finger interacts with the existing electric field, inducing a weak electric current.

options.label: C
options.text: Your finger has no effect on the touchscreen.

options.label: D
options.text: Your finger damages the touchscreen.

multiple-choice.question: Why might you have trouble using a smartphone with wet or gloved hands?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the water or gloves improve the electrical connection between your finger and the phone.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the water or gloves interrupt the electrical connection between your finger and the phone.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the water or gloves have no effect on the electrical connection between your finger and the phone.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the water or gloves damage the phone.

multiple-choice.question: What type of objects can activate a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: Only human fingers

options.label: B
options.text: Only styluses

options.label: C
options.text: Objects that conduct electricity about as well as a human finger, such as banana peels and certain processed meats

options.label: D
options.text: Any object

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential problem with using a capacitive touchscreen in wet conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: The screen may become unresponsive.

options.label: B
options.text: The screen may be damaged.

options.label: C
options.text: The phone may act like you've touched it in multiple places at once.

options.label: D
options.text: The phone may shut down.

title: This weird trick will help you summon an army of worms - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the practice of using noise to make earthworms emerge from the soil?

options.label: A
options.text: Worm charming

options.label: B
options.text: Worm grunting

options.label: C
options.text: Worm fiddling

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the result of Kenneth Catania's experiment testing the hypothesis that worm grunting mimicked falling rain?

options.label: A
options.text: Most earthworms emerged to avoid drowning

options.label: B
options.text: Only two earthworms emerged, while the rest remained buried

options.label: C
options.text: The earthworms burrowed deeper to avoid the vibrations

options.label: D
options.text: The experiment was inconclusive

multiple-choice.question: If you were a farmer trying to control mole populations in your fields, how might you apply the knowledge about worm grunting and mole predation?

options.label: A
options.text: By using worm grunting to lure moles into traps

options.label: B
options.text: By creating vibrations to scare moles away

options.label: C
options.text: By introducing more earthworms to the soil to distract the moles

options.label: D
options.text: By using pesticides to kill both moles and earthworms

multiple-choice.question: What is the title of Charles Darwin's book that discusses earthworm behavior and habits?

options.label: A
options.text: "The Origin of Species"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Formation of Vegetable Mould, Through the Action of Worms, with Observations on their Habits"

options.label: C
options.text: "The Descent of Man"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Expression of Emotions in Man and Animals"

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the relationship between worm grunting, moles, and earthworms. What can be inferred about the evolutionary pressures on earthworms?

options.label: A
options.text: Earthworms evolved to flee from moles due to predation pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Earthworms evolved to ignore moles and focus on other predators

options.label: C
options.text: Earthworms evolved to cooperate with moles for mutual benefit

options.label: D
options.text: Earthworms evolved to compete with moles for resources

multiple-choice.question: How do herring gulls and wood turtles take advantage of the earthworms' behavior, and what does this reveal about the adaptability of prey species?

options.label: A
options.text: They use worm grunting to catch earthworms, showing that prey species are vulnerable to multiple predators

options.label: B
options.text: They use worm grunting to scare earthworms away, showing that prey species can adapt to multiple threats

options.label: C
options.text: They use worm grunting to communicate with earthworms, showing that prey species can cooperate with other species

options.label: D
options.text: They use worm grunting to mimic moles, showing that prey species can evolve to evade specific predators

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the statement: "Prey species should always prioritize adapting to the most frequent predator." Do you agree or disagree, and why?

options.label: A
options.text: Agree, because it ensures the greatest survival rate

options.label: B
options.text: Disagree, because it may lead to vulnerability to other predators

options.label: C
options.text: Agree, because it allows for specialization in defense mechanisms

options.label: D
options.text: Disagree, because it neglects the importance of adapting to environmental changes

multiple-choice.question: What is the current world record for "most worms charmed," and how was it achieved?

options.label: A
options.text: 100 worms, achieved by using a specialized tool

options.label: B
options.text: 567 worms, achieved by a 10-year-old girl using a fork and stick

options.label: C
options.text: 500 worms, achieved by a team of professional worm grunters

options.label: D
options.text: 1000 worms, achieved by using a machine designed for worm grunting

multiple-choice.question: Synthesize the information about worm grunting, moles, and earthworms to propose a new hypothesis about the evolution of earthworm behavior. What predictions would this hypothesis make, and how could it be tested?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypothesis: Earthworms evolved to flee from moles due to predation pressure. Predictions: Earthworms will emerge more frequently in areas with high mole populations. Test: Compare earthworm emergence rates in areas with high and low mole populations.

options.label: B
options.text: Hypothesis: Earthworms evolved to cooperate with moles for mutual benefit. Predictions: Earthworms will emerge more frequently in areas with low mole populations. Test: Compare earthworm emergence rates in areas with high and low mole populations.

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothesis: Earthworms evolved to ignore moles and focus on other predators. Predictions: Earthworms will emerge at the same rate regardless of mole population. Test: Compare earthworm emergence rates in areas with high and low mole populations.

options.label: D
options.text: Hypothesis: Earthworms evolved to compete with moles for resources. Predictions: Earthworms will emerge more frequently in areas with high resource availability. Test: Compare earthworm emergence rates in areas with high and low resource availability.

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the adaptability of prey species based on the example of the painted redstart and its prey?

options.label: A
options.text: Prey species can adapt to specific predators, but may remain vulnerable to other predators

options.label: B
options.text: Prey species can evolve to evade all predators simultaneously

options.label: C
options.text: Prey species can cooperate with predators for mutual benefit

options.label: D
options.text: Prey species are limited in their ability to adapt to changing predator populations

title: The true cost of gold - Lyla Latif

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate value of one kilogram of gold in US dollars?

options.label: A
options.text: Mali, Mauritania, Senegal, and Ghana

options.label: B
options.text: Mali, Mauritania, Senegal, Guinea, Cote d’Ivoire, Ghana, Burkina Faso, and Niger

options.label: C
options.text: South Africa, Egypt, and Morocco

options.label: D
options.text: Ethiopia, Kenya, and Tanzania

options.text: Lack of skilled labor

options.label: B
options.text: Limited gold reserves

options.label: C
options.text: Lack of infrastructure

options.label: D
options.text: Government corruption

options.text: By offering favorable contracts with high tax rates

options.label: B
options.text: By investing in Mali's infrastructure

options.label: C
options.text: By signing contracts with favorable terms for the corporations, such as tax exemptions

options.label: A
options.text: By exaggerating their profits

options.label: B
options.text: By filtering profits through a labyrinth of tax havens

options.label: C
options.text: By paying taxes on time

options.label: D
options.text: By investing in local communities

multiple-choice.question: How do local, small-scale miners operate in Mali, and what is the consequence?

options.label: A
options.text: They operate with licenses, and the government collects taxes on their gold

options.label: B
options.text: They operate without licenses, and corporations buy their gold at market value

options.label: C
options.text: They operate without licenses, and corporations buy their gold at below market value, causing the country to lose tax money

options.label: D
options.text: They operate with licenses, but the government does not collect taxes on their gold

options.text: $200 million

options.label: B
options.text: $1.5 billion

options.label: C
options.text: $500 million

options.label: D
options.text: $1 billion

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of the corrupt system in Mali's gold industry?

options.label: A
options.text: The country's economy is boosted, and citizens' living standards improve

options.label: B
options.text: The country's economy is stagnant, but citizens' living standards remain unchanged

options.label: C
options.text: The country's economy is weakened, and more than half of its citizens live below the international poverty line

options.label: D
options.text: The country's economy is strengthened, but the environment is degraded

multiple-choice.question: How do corporations benefit from buying gold from local, small-scale miners in Mali?

options.label: A
options.text: They incur huge expenses mining the gold themselves

options.label: B
options.text: They pay the miners market value and operate through legal channels

options.label: C
options.text: They avoid the cost of mining the gold themselves and pay the miners below market value

options.label: D
options.text: They pay taxes on the gold purchased from the miners

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall effect of the situation in Mali's gold industry?

options.label: A
options.text: A virtuous cycle of economic growth and development

options.label: B
options.text: A vicious cycle of reliance on foreign corporations and continued poverty

options.label: C
options.text: A stable economy with minimal growth

options.label: D
options.text: A rapidly developing economy with improved living standards

title: The 4 greatest threats to the survival of humanity

multiple-choice.question: In what year did Russia detect a nuclear missile headed its way, which was later found to be a research rocket studying the Northern Lights?

options.label: A
options.text: Existential risk

options.label: B
options.text: Global risk

options.label: C
options.text: Humanitarian risk

options.label: D
options.text: Natural risk

multiple-choice.question: According to experts, what is the estimated risk of human extinction from natural threats per century?
What is the primary concern regarding the development of superintelligent AI?

options.label: A
options.text: That it will surpass human intelligence and become uncontrollable

options.label: B
options.text: That it will be too expensive to develop and maintain

options.label: C
options.text: That it will lead to significant job losses

options.label: D
options.text: That it will not be perfectly aligned with human values

options.label: B
options.text: Economic collapse, leading to widespread poverty

options.label: C
options.text: Environmental disaster, causing widespread pollution

options.label: D
options.text: Social unrest, leading to global conflict

options.label: B
options.text: Biotechnology

options.label: C
options.text: Nanotechnology

options.label: D
options.text: Robotics

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the estimated anthropogenic existential risk compared to the background rate of natural risk?

options.label: A
options.text: More than 10 times higher

options.label: B
options.text: More than 100 times higher

options.label: C
options.text: More than 1,000 times higher

options.label: D
options.text: More than 10,000 times higher

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why assessing existential risk is an inherently uncertain business?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there is not enough data available

options.label: B
options.text: Because the complete destruction of humanity has never happened before

options.label: C
options.text: Because the risks are too complex to understand

options.label: D
options.text: Because the consequences are too severe to contemplate

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential consequence of climate change that could make humanity more vulnerable to other existential risks?

options.label: A
options.text: Rising sea levels

options.label: B
options.text: Increased frequency of natural disasters

options.label: C
options.text: Disruption to global food systems

options.label: D
options.text: Disruption to global economic systems

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the key factor that will determine whether humanity fulfills its potential or not?

options.label: A
options.text: Technological advancements

options.label: B
options.text: Economic growth

options.label: C
options.text: Human choices

options.label: D
options.text: Natural disasters

title: What causes yeast infections, and how do you get rid of them? - Liesbeth Demuyser

title: The world’s slimiest animal - Noah R. Bressman and Douglas Fudge

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the 2017 car accident involving a truck carrying live hagfish?

options.label: A
options.text: The highway was littered with dead fish and debris.

options.label: B
options.text: The highway was littered with wriggling fish and coated in a thick slime.

options.label: C
options.text: The truck driver was injured and taken to the hospital.

options.label: D
options.text: The accident caused a massive traffic jam.

multiple-choice.question: What is the standout strength of all hagfishes?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to detect dead fish using their keen sense of smell.

options.label: B
options.text: Their imposing rows of toothlike structures.

options.label: C
options.text: Their slime.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to survive without oxygen for 36 hours.

multiple-choice.question: How do hagfish protect themselves from predators like sharks?

options.label: A
options.text: By using their toothlike structures to defend themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: By releasing a cloud of slime that lodges in the shark's gills.

options.label: C
options.text: By swimming away quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: By using their four little hearts to pump more blood.

multiple-choice.question: What is the composition of hagfish slime?

options.label: A
options.text: Mucus and water.

options.label: B
options.text: Mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine and strong silk-like fibers.

options.label: C
options.text: Protein fibers and water.

options.label: D
options.text: Mucus and toothlike structures.

multiple-choice.question: Why are researchers interested in emulating hagfish slime?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is incredibly soft and fragile.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is incredibly soft yet tough and could be used to create sustainable materials.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is only found in hagfish.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not useful for any practical applications.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential military application of hagfish slime?

options.label: A
options.text: As a lethal weapon to kill enemy soldiers.

options.label: B
options.text: As a non-lethal weapon to stop boats by sliming up their propellers.

options.label: C
options.text: As a tool for espionage.

options.label: D
options.text: As a way to protect against chemical attacks.

multiple-choice.question: How do hagfish clean themselves after releasing slime?

options.label: A
options.text: By swimming through a school of fish to wipe away the slime.

options.label: B
options.text: By using their toothlike structures to scrape off the slime.

options.label: C
options.text: By tying themselves in a knot to wipe away the slime.

options.label: D
options.text: By using their four little hearts to pump more blood.

multiple-choice.question: What is another unique feature of hagfish besides their slime?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to survive without oxygen for 36 hours.

options.label: B
options.text: Their four little hearts.

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to tie themselves in knots.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What role do hagfish play in the ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They are apex predators and regulate the population of other sea creatures.

options.label: B
options.text: They clean the seafloor and cycle essential nutrients in the deep sea.

options.label: C
options.text: They are prey for many other sea creatures and help to support the food chain.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no significant role in the ecosystem.

multiple-choice.question: How long have hagfish been present on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: For over 100 million years.

options.label: B
options.text: For over 300 million years.

options.label: C
options.text: For over 500 million years.

options.label: D
options.text: For over 1 billion years.

title: What’s the best country to live in?

multiple-choice.question: Who invented the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the 1930s?

options.label: A
options.text: King Jigme Singye Wangchuk

options.label: B
options.text: Simon Kuznets

options.label: C
options.text: John Maynard Keynes

options.label: D
options.text: Milton Friedman

multiple-choice.question: What does GDP per capita represent?

options.label: A
options.text: Total GDP divided by the number of businesses in a country

options.label: B
options.text: Total GDP divided by the number of people living in a country

options.label: C
options.text: Total GDP multiplied by the number of people living in a country

options.label: D
options.text: Total GDP minus the number of people living in a country

options.label: B
options.text: The country's well-being is not necessarily reflected by its GDP

options.label: C
options.text: The country's well-being is inversely proportional to its GDP

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It only accounts for non-monetary transactions

options.label: C
options.text: It only accounts for government spending

options.label: D
options.text: It only accounts for international trade

options.label: A
options.text: Economic growth

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental sustainability

options.label: C
options.text: Overall well-being

options.label: D
options.text: Military strength

options.label: A
options.text: Costa Rica

options.label: B
options.text: Colombia

options.label: C
options.text: Jordan

options.label: D
options.text: United States

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using a dashboard approach to measure well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a single, easy-to-understand number

options.label: B
options.text: It obscures various factors that affect well-being

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for a more comprehensive understanding of well-being

options.label: D
options.text: It is easier to calculate than a single metric

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Only health and education outcomes

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of economic, social, and environmental factors

options.label: D
options.text: Only military strength and international influence

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the Sustainable Development Index and the Human Development Index?

options.label: A
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index only accounts for economic growth, while the Human Development Index only accounts for health and education

options.label: B
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index accounts for environmental burdens, while the Human Development Index does not

options.label: C
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index only accounts for social factors, while the Human Development Index only accounts for economic factors

options.label: D
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index is used for developed countries, while the Human Development Index is used for developing countries

multiple-choice.question: Why do experts increasingly favor a dashboard approach to measuring well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it provides a single, easy-to-understand number

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows for a more comprehensive understanding of well-being

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is easier to calculate than a single metric

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is less accurate than a single metric

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate barometric pressure at the top of Mt. Everest compared to sea level?
What happens to the oxygen levels in the air as altitude increases?

options.label: A
options.text: The relative amounts of oxygen increase

options.label: B
options.text: The relative amounts of oxygen remain the same, but overall oxygen levels decrease

options.label: C
options.text: The relative amounts of oxygen decrease

options.label: D
options.text: The relative amounts of oxygen remain the same, and overall oxygen levels increase

multiple-choice.question: A person is planning to climb a mountain with an altitude of 3,000 meters. What advice would you give them to avoid altitude sickness?

options.label: A
options.text: Ascend to the summit as quickly as possible

options.label: B
options.text: Ascend gradually, taking several weeks to acclimate to the high altitude

options.label: C
options.text: Stay at sea level for a month before ascending

options.label: D
options.text: Take medication to prevent altitude sickness

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of carotid chemoreceptors in the neck when sensing low oxygen pressure at high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: To decrease heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: B
options.text: To increase heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain normal heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease blood pressure

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the decrease in plasma volume in the blood after several days at high altitude?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased concentration of hemoglobin

options.label: B
options.text: Increased concentration of hemoglobin

options.label: C
options.text: No change in hemoglobin concentration

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased heart rate

options.label: A
options.text: HAPE

options.label: B
options.text: HACE

options.label: C
options.text: AMS

options.label: D
options.text: Hypoxia

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the relationship between altitude and oxygen levels in the air. How do these factors impact the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: As altitude increases, oxygen levels decrease, leading to increased heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: B
options.text: As altitude increases, oxygen levels increase, leading to decreased heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: C
options.text: As altitude increases, oxygen levels remain the same, leading to no changes in heart rate and breathing rate

options.label: D
options.text: As altitude decreases, oxygen levels decrease, leading to increased heart rate and breathing rate

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the genetic advantages of Tibetans and South Americans who have lived at high altitudes for generations?

options.label: A
options.text: They are immune to all forms of altitude sickness

options.label: B
options.text: They are more susceptible to severe altitude sickness

options.label: C
options.text: They have a lower risk of minor altitude sickness, but are not immune to severe conditions

options.label: D
options.text: They have no genetic advantages related to high altitude adaptation

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the risks and benefits of climbing to extreme altitudes. What can be concluded about human adaptation to high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: Humans are not capable of adapting to high altitudes and should avoid climbing to extreme elevations

options.label: B
options.text: Humans can adapt to high altitudes, but only with extensive training and acclimatization

options.label: C
options.text: Humans can adapt to high altitudes, and with proper acclimatization, can climb to extreme elevations with minimal risk

options.label: D
options.text: Humans are naturally adapted to high altitudes and do not require acclimatization

multiple-choice.question: Synthesize the information about high altitude adaptation and propose a plan for a climber to ascend to the summit of Mt. Everest safely.

options.label: A
options.text: Ascend to the summit in one day, taking regular breaks to rest and acclimate

options.label: B
options.text: Ascend to the summit over the course of several weeks, taking time to acclimate to each new altitude

options.label: C
options.text: Ascend to the summit in a few days, using medication to prevent altitude sickness

options.label: D
options.text: Ascend to the summit alone, without any prior experience or acclimatization

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What was the notable change observed in the parrot that went missing in 2010 when it was reunited with its owner four years later?

options.label: A
options.text: It had grown significantly larger.

options.label: B
options.text: It had lost its ability to speak.

options.label: C
options.text: It had changed its British accent to a Spanish accent.

options.label: D
options.text: It had become more aggressive.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a unique characteristic of parrots compared to other birds?

options.label: A
options.text: They have two vibrating membranes in their syrinx.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a highly developed sense of smell.

options.label: C
options.text: They have especially flexible, powerful tongues.

options.label: D
options.text: They have rigid beak joints.

options.label: A
options.text: To attract mates.

options.label: B
options.text: To warn off predators.

options.label: C
options.text: To interact and stay in touch with other parrots when they are out of sight.

options.label: B
options.text: Larynx

options.label: C
options.text: Tongue

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: They have a highly developed sense of hearing.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a large brain-to-body mass ratio.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a need for sophisticated mimicry due to their social behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a unique genetic trait.

multiple-choice.question: If you were to train a parrot to learn a new phrase, what would be the most effective way to do so?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat the phrase multiple times and reward the parrot with treats.

options.label: B
options.text: Play a recording of the phrase and have the parrot mimic it.

options.label: C
options.text: Use a combination of visual and auditory cues to help the parrot associate the phrase with a meaning.

options.label: D
options.text: Train the parrot in a group setting with other parrots.

options.label: A
options.text: Alex

options.label: B
options.text: Polly

options.label: C
options.text: Charlie

options.label: D
options.text: Sunny

options.text: Parrots have a smaller brain-to-body mass ratio.

options.label: B
options.text: Parrots have a single song system, while songbirds have multiple systems.

options.label: C
options.text: Parrots have an additional circuit in their brain that may give them extra flexibility in learning calls.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Habitat destruction due to deforestation.

options.label: B
options.text: Climate change.

options.label: C
options.text: Poaching and pet trade.

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and C.

options.label: B
options.text: Preserving and studying them in the wild.

options.label: C

options.label: D
